content:
I found https://github.com/bhgomes/lean-riemann-hypothesis from @Brandon Gomes and @Alex Kontorovich, but I guess it's not compatible with Lean4.

Does there exist a Lean4-compatible formalization of the RH?
Interestingly that formalization seems to deliberately avoid using mathlib at all
Searching for proof_wanted I didnâ€™t find it among the ones we have, but we do have docs#riemannZeta and a bit of API, so just stating RH should be straightforward
How did I not see it in the docs :man_facepalming:
Hey, you did all the work for me to find that

So:

theorem good_luck : RiemannHypothesis := sorry

where that sorry is probably worth $1000000
Michael Bucko has marked this topic as resolved.
Considering you can collect $1000000 without filling it in doesn't that mean it's worth $0?
I look forward to the first 1000-page LLM-generated informal "proof" of RH; maybe the math community's reaction to it will be "it would be a darn sight easier if you just filled it in"

There are some nice, very short statements in pure first order arithmetic (Peano arithmetic) which are equivalent to RH. (https://mathoverflow.net/questions/31846/is-the-riemann-hypothesis-equivalent-to-a-pi-1-sentence). It would be a nice challenge to show their formulation is equivalent to one of those.

Kevin Buzzard schrieb:

I look forward to the first 1000-page LLM-generated informal "proof" of RH; maybe the math community's reaction to it will be "it would be a darn sight easier if you just filled it in"

I look forward to the first fully formalized one.

On the other hand, it'd be fun if AI could help find a counterexample.

My first bet would be to look into search at scale (again -- since some had tried, but the search tech has changed a lot since then, and perhaps LLMs could optimize such search at scale).

Eric Wieser said:

Interestingly that formalization seems to deliberately avoid using mathlib at all

Indeed, Brandon wanted (for reasons that still escape me) make it as independent of Mathlib as possible, so we axiomatized things like the exponential function and some of its properties. That said, we also included a "witness" file that all of our "axioms" can be proved from facts within Mathlib...
